description: From Middle English dere, from Old English dīere (“of great value or excellence, expensive, beloved”), from Proto-West Germanic *diurī, from Proto-Germanic *diurijaz (“dear, precious, expensive”). Cognate with Scots dere, deir (“of great value or worth, highly valued, precious, beloved”), Saterland Frisian djuur (“precious, dear, costly, expensive”), Dutch duur (“costly, precious”), German teuer (“costly, precious”), German Low German düür, Danish dyr (“expensive”), Swedish dyr (“expensive”), Norwegian dyr (“expensive”), Icelandic dýr (“expensive”), Yiddish טייַער‎ (tayer, “precious,expensive”).

examples: The dearer the jewel, the greater the love expressed.

So this was my future home, I thought! […] Backed by towering hills, the but faintly discernible purple line of the French boundary off to the southwest, a sky of palest Gobelin flecked with fat, fleecy little clouds, it in truth looked a dear little city; the city of one's dreams.
Such dear embrace tenderly comforts even in this dear sorrow.

entries.meaning: Precious to or greatly valued by someone.
examples: The dearer the giver, the dearer the trinket he brings!

entries.meaning: A formal way to start (possibly after my) addressing somebody at the beginning of a letter, memo etc.
examples: Dear Sir/Madam/Miss, please notice our offices will be closed during the following bank holidays: […].

entries.meaning: A formal way to start (often after my) addressing somebody one likes or regards kindly.
examples: My dear friend, I feel better as soon as you come sit beside my sickbed!

entries.meaning: An ironic way to start (often after my) addressing an inferior.
examples: My dear boy, if your grades don't pick up I won't bounce you on, but over my knee!

adverbs.description: dear (comparative more dear, superlative most dear)

examples: My little cousin is such a dear, always drawing me pictures.

entries.meaning: An affectionate, familiar term of address, such as used between husband and wife.
examples: Pass me the salt, would you dear?

entries.meaning: An elderly person, especially a woman.

verbs.description: dear (third-person singular simple present dears, present participle dearing, simple past and past participle deared)

description: From Middle English dere (“fierce, severe, hard, deadly”), from Old English dēor, dȳr (“brave, bold; severe, dire, vehement”), from Proto-Germanic *deuzaz. Cognate with the above.

adjectives.description: dear (comparative more dear, superlative most dear)

examples: The Christens found the heathens dear, as the lion doth the bear.
